abstractContent.text: Topic modeling of fashion trends were analyzed using the MALLET toolkit.
Harper's Bazaar magazines from 1860-1899 were used (freely available online).
This resulted in 20 topics with 4 characterizing words each.
Trends overtime were analyzed in several different ways using 100-topics and 20-topics.

introductionContent.text: Using trend analysis to extract topics from a fashion magazine may finally put to rest the question of the cyclicality of fashion.
Entire issues of Harper's Bazaar from the 19 th century are freely available online.

entities.text: Harper's Bazaar from the 19 th century

introductionContent.text: Preliminary data analysis using the NLTK toolkit in Python did not yield promising results.
Bigram collocations were extracted for the first three years of data.
The collocations were extracted on a monthly basis, however the bigrams were extremely non-specific and contained no relevant information.
Topic modeling is the natural choice for large amounts of historical data, so this was the strategy implemented for the second attempt.
Extracting this data and applying the MALLET toolkit for topic modeling provided a good start and a novel way of looking at fashion trends.
